discussion.p: The absence of explicit description of std::complex<T> layout makes it imposible to reuse existing software developed in traditional languages like Fortran or C with unambigous and commonly accepted layout assumptions. There ought to be a way for practitioners to predict with confidence the layout of std::complex<T> whenever T is a numerical datatype. The absence of ways to access individual parts of a std::complex<T> object as lvalues unduly promotes severe pessimizations. For example, the only way to change, independently, the real and imaginary parts is to write something like

At this point, it seems appropriate to recall that a complex number is, in effect, just a pair of numbers with no particular invariant to maintain. Existing practice in numerical computations has it that a complex number datatype is usually represented by Cartesian coordinates. Therefore the over-encapsulation put in the specification of std::complex<> is not justified.

resolution.p: Add the following requirements to as 26.3/4:

blockquote.p: If z is an lvalue expression of type cv std::complex<T> then

ul.li: the expression reinterpret_cast<cv T(&)[2]>(z) is well-formed; and
reinterpret_cast<cv T(&)[2]>(z)[0]designates the real part of z; and
reinterpret_cast<cv T(&)[2]>(z)[1]designates the imaginary part of z.

blockquote.p: Moreover, if a is an expression of pointer type cv complex<T>* and the expression a[i] is well-defined for an integer expression i then:

ul.li: reinterpret_cast<cv T*>(a)[2*i] designates the real part of a[i]; and
reinterpret_cast<cv T*>(a)[2*i+1] designates the imaginary part of a[i].

resolution.p: In and add the following member functions (changing T to concrete types as appropriate for the specializations).

blockquote.blockquote: Returns: the value of the real component
Assigns val to the real component.
Returns: the value of the imaginary component
Assigns val to the imaginary component.

resolution.note: Kona: The layout guarantee is absolutely necessary for C compatibility. However, there was disagreement about the other part of this proposal: retrieving elements of the complex number as lvalues. An alternative: continue to have real() and imag() return rvalues, but add set_real() and set_imag(). Straw poll: return lvalues - 2, add setter functions - 5. Related issue: do we want reinterpret_cast as the interface for converting a complex to an array of two reals, or do we want to provide a more explicit way of doing it? Howard will try to resolve this issue for the next meeting.

rationale.p: The LWG believes that C99 compatibility would be enough justification for this change even without other considerations. All existing implementations already have the layout proposed here.
